title: How to Make Gomasio

steps.headline: Heat a cast iron frying pan over moderate heat.
Move the salt around the pan until it is thoroughly dry.
Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Tip the salt into a mortar and pestle. Grind until it is fine.

steps.headline: Using the same cast iron pan, add the 15 teaspoons of sesame seeds.
steps.description: Swirl over the moderate heat until the seeds crack. To test the seeds, place one between the thumb and finger and press. If it cracks, it is ready.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Tip the heated sesame seeds into a mortar and pestle. Grind until half (50 percent) of the sesame seeds are cracked and ground.

steps.headline: Pour the salt in and mix thoroughly.
Pour the gomasio into a suitable clean and dry container.
steps.description: Seal. Store in the fridge, as ground sesame seeds turn rancid quickly.

steps.headline: Use.
steps.description: Gomasio is delicious, and is excellent as a replacement for salt and pepper.

text: Heat a cast iron frying pan over moderate heat. Add 1 teaspoon of sea salt. Move the salt around the pan until it is thoroughly dry.  Remove from the heat. Tip the salt into a mortar and pestle. Grind until it is fine. Using the same cast iron pan, add the 15 teaspoons of sesame seeds. Swirl over the moderate heat until the seeds crack. To test the seeds, place one between the thumb and finger and press. If it cracks, it is ready. Remove from the heat. Tip the heated sesame seeds into a mortar and pestle. Grind until half (50 percent) of the sesame seeds are cracked and ground. Pour the salt in and mix thoroughly.  Pour the gomasio into a suitable clean and dry container. Seal. Store in the fridge, as ground sesame seeds turn rancid quickly. Use. Gomasio is delicious, and is excellent as a replacement for salt and pepper.
